title: Bush-Francis Catatonia Rating Scale
description: Assesses severity of catatonia and screens for catatonia in psychiatric and neurological conditions. The first 14 items comprise the screening instrument. If 2 or more of the first 14 items are positive, this indicates a positive screening and should prompt completion of 9 additional items.

parameters.name: excitement
parameters.description: Extreme hyperactivity, constant motor unrest which is apparently non-purposeful

parameters.name: immobility_stupor
parameters.description: Extreme hypoactivity, immobile, minimally responsive to stimuli

parameters.name: mutism
parameters.description: Verbally unresponsive or minimally responsive

parameters.name: staring
parameters.description: Fixed gaze, little or no visual scanning of environment, decreased blinking

parameters.name: posturing_catalepsy
parameters.description: Spontaneous maintenance of posture(s), including mundane (e.g., sitting or standing for long periods without reacting)

parameters.name: grimacing
parameters.description: Maintenance of odd facial expressions

parameters.name: echopraxia_echolalia
parameters.description: Mimicking of examiner's movements/speech

parameters.name: stereotypy
parameters.description: Repetitive, non-goal-directed motor activity (e.g., finger-play, repeatedly touching, patting, or rubbing self)

parameters.name: mannerisms
parameters.description: Odd, purposeful movements (e.g., hopping or walking tiptoe, saluting passers-by, or exaggerated caricatures of mundane movements)

parameters.name: verbigeration
parameters.description: Repetition of phrases or sentences (like a scratched record)

parameters.name: rigidity
parameters.description: Maintenance of a rigid position despite efforts to be moved, exclude if cogwheel rigidity or tremor present

parameters.name: negativism
parameters.description: Apparently motiveless resistance to instructions or attempts to move/examine patient. Contrary behavior, does exact opposite of instruction

parameters.name: waxy_flexibility
parameters.description: During reposturing of patient, patient offers initial resistance before allowing themselves to be repositioned, similar to that of a bending candle

parameters.name: withdrawal
parameters.description: Refusal to eat, drink, and/or make eye contact

parameters.name: impulsivity
parameters.description: Patient suddenly engages in inappropriate behavior (e.g., runs down hallway, starts screaming, or takes off clothes) without provocation. Afterwards can give no, or only a facile explanation

parameters.name: automatic_obedience
parameters.description: Exaggerated cooperation with examiner's request or spontaneous continuation of movement requested

parameters.name: passive_obedience
parameters.description: Mitgehen. 'Anglepoise lamp' arm raising in response to light pressure of finger, despite instruction to resist

parameters.name: muscle_resistance
parameters.description: Gegenhalten. Resistance to passive movement which is proportional to strength of the stimulus; appears automatic rather than willful

parameters.name: motorically_stuck
parameters.description: Ambitendency. Patient appears motorically 'stuck' in indecisive, hesitant movement

parameters.name: grasp_reflex
parameters.description: Per neurological exam

parameters.name: perseveration
parameters.description: Repeatedly returns to same topic or persists with same movements

parameters.name: combativeness
parameters.description: Usually in an undirected manner, with no, or only a facile explanation afterwards

parameters.name: autonomic_abnormality
parameters.description: Temperature, BP, pulse, or respiratory rate abnormality; diaphoresis

result.name: total_score
result.description: Total Bush-Francis Catatonia Rating Scale score

ranges.interpretation: Less than 2 items positive in screening instrument. Catatonia is unlikely. Consider other diagnoses or re-evaluate if clinical suspicion remains high.

Two or more items positive in screening instrument indicates positive screening for catatonia. Complete full 23-item assessment. Higher scores indicate greater severity. Consider immediate treatment, particularly if autonomic instability is present.

references: Bush G, Fink M, Petrides G, Dowling F, Francis A. Catatonia. I. Rating scale and standardized examination. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 1996;93(2):129-36.
Bush G, Fink M, Petrides G, Dowling F, Francis A. Catatonia. II. Treatment with lorazepam and electroconvulsive therapy. Acta Psychiatr Scand. 1996;93(2):137-143.
Francis A. Catatonia: diagnosis, classification, and treatment. Curr Psychiatry Rep. 2010;12(3):180-5.
Sienaert P, Dhossche DM, Vancampfort D, De Hert M, Gazdag G. A clinical review of the treatment of catatonia. Front Psychiatry. 2014;5:181.
formula: Total Score = Sum of all 23 items (0-69 points). Screening positive if ≥2 of first 14 items are positive (score ≥1).
notes: The first 14 items constitute the Bush-Francis Catatonia Screening Instrument (BFCSI)
Items 13 and 17-21 are scored as either 0 (absent) or 3 (present) only
The BFCRS is not a standalone diagnostic tool and should be used with comprehensive psychiatric evaluation
Catatonia is a medical emergency when associated with autonomic instability (malignant catatonia)
